Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: Second Assistant U.S. Secretary of State

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, La, Aug. 11, 1882.

Mr. J. H. Smyth to the
Second Ass't Sec'y of State.
Contract with Mrs Matilda A. Roberts, and leave from Mrs. Jane Rose Roberts.
The contract of rent made between Mrs. Matilda A. Roberts and late Minister Garnet & lease of the Robert's mansion from Mrs. Jane Rose Roberts.

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, La, Aug. 11, 1882.

In your No. 6, dated June 26, 1882, you were pleased to advise Mr. Aenmey, Vice Consul General of the U.S. in charge that, the contract made between Minister Garnet & Mrs. Roberts for a building for the Consulate General–was binding upon the Government for its fulfilment, and that he should 'settle with Mrs. R. upon the most favorable terms of compromise.'

Mr. A. failed, or concluded not to
Hon. W. Hunter,
Second Ass't Sec'y of State,
Washington, D.C.
to proceed in the matter of compromise, because he anticipated my early arrival; and on my arrival requested me to attend to the matter.

Mrs. R. visited me, and after a full canvass of the subject, I concluded succeeded in getting her to wave all claim to two years rent, and to accept in full satisfaction of the contract the balance due for the year 1882, which was $145.00/100; there having been made two payments on account, one of $25.00, and one of $30. I paid the $145. by draft on the Secretary of State in favor of Mrs. Matilda A. Roberts, and took her receipt for the same, which I enclose
enclose as voucher, No. 1.

There remained an unsettled balance of one quarter's rent for the Roberts mansion for the quarter. A portion of this mansion was based by me at the rate of $200. per annum. for the use of the legation, when I was in office, and this building was turned over to my successor Hon. H. H. Garnet, &c., &c., &c., &c., but he failed to keep the premises, and to pay for the quarter which expired during his term of office.
I have this day drawn a draft for the due and unpaid December quarter 1881–in favor of the lessor Jane Rose Roberts, for $50.

These
These two drafts cover all the Government's indebtedness for rent. See voucher No. 2.

With sentiments of high esteem,
I am, Sir,
Your obd't serv't,
Jno. H. Smyth, U.S.
Consul General.

No. 1 Receipt – Matilda A. Roberts.
No. 2 Receipt – Jane Rose Roberts.
